An element of a set is an object belonging to a set.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.
Does the concept of a/an Element of a Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Irreducible Polynomial to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To understand whether the concept of an 'Element of a Set' is necessary for the definition of an 'Irreducible Polynomial', we need to analyze the components of the definition of an irreducible polynomial:

1. A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ implies that $f$ is an element of the set $R[X]$, which is the set of all polynomials with coefficients in the ring $R$.
2. The definition states that $f$ cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$. This implies that these two non-constant polynomials must also be elements of the set $R[X]$.

Thus, the concept of an element being part of a set is fundamental to defining what it means for a polynomial to be in $R[X]$ and for other polynomials to be factors of $f$. Without understanding that polynomials are elements of the set $R[X]$, the definition of irreducibility, which relies on the ability to identify and manipulate these elements (polynomials), would not be coherent.
